t: Job 3
After*p this opened Job his mouth, and cursed his day.
And*p Job spake, and said,
Let*p the day perish wherein I was born, and the night in which it was said, There is a man child conceived.
Let*p that day be darkness; let not God regard it from above, neither let the light shine upon it.
Let*p darkness and the shadow of death stain it; let a cloud dwell upon it; let the blackness of the day terrify it.
As*p for that night, let darkness seize upon it; let it not be joined unto the days of the year, let it not come into the number of the months.
Lo,*p let that night be solitary, let no joyful voice come therein.
Let*p them curse it that curse the day, who are ready to raise up their mourning.
Let*p the stars of the twilight thereof be dark; let it look for light, but have none; neither let it see the dawning of the day:
Because*p it shut not up the doors of my mother's womb, nor hid sorrow from mine eyes.
Why*p died I not from the womb? why did I not give up the ghost when I came out of the belly?
Why*p did the knees prevent me? or why the breasts that I should suck?
For*p now should I have lain still and been quiet, I should have slept: then had I been at rest,
With*p kings and counsellors of the earth, which built desolate places for themselves;
Or*p with princes that had gold, who filled their houses with silver:
Or*p as an hidden untimely birth I had not been; as infants which never saw light.
There*p the wicked cease from troubling; and there the weary be at rest.
There*p the prisoners rest together; they hear not the voice of the oppressor.
The*p small and great are there; and the servant is free from his master.
Wherefore*p is light given to him that is in misery, and life unto the bitter in soul;
Which*p long for death, but it cometh not; and dig for it more than for hid treasures;
Which*p rejoice exceedingly, and are glad, when they can find the grave?
Why*p is light given to a man whose way is hid, and whom God hath hedged in?
For*p my sighing cometh before I eat, and my roarings are poured out like the waters.
For*p the thing which I greatly feared is come upon me, and that which I was afraid of is come unto me.
I*p was not in safety, neither had I rest, neither was I quiet; yet trouble came.
